attributes.title: Replication of Comparative Studies of Detecting Abusive Language on Twitter
attributes.description: This is the replication project for the Winter 2020 Data Reproducibility course in the Master of Data Science program at University of Washington.

attributes.title: Inclusion, Identity, and the Corona Pandemic
attributes.description: Brewer’s (1991) Optimal Distinctiveness Theory (ODT) suggests a two-dimensional model of inclusion (See Figure 1). She argues that for an individual to identify with a group, the individual does not only need to assimilate with the group members, but simultaneously satisfy differentiation needs. The outbreak of the COVID-19 virus in Europe in late February and early March has affected societies dramatically, such that schools and universities were closed, regions were isolated from the rest of the country, or travel bans were administered. Governments call citizens to responsibility, such that they ask to unify against this collective challenge and adhere to governmental regulations. Meanwhile, specific subgroups – such as individuals from particular areas, the elderly, chronically ill people, or families – have special needs that citizens are being asked to take care for. We thus expect this corona pandemic to increase both superordinate collective identity and subgroup identities as the virus develops. The virus seems to become a more serious issue in the US as of March 12th, 2020. We will thus immediately assess baseline measures (t1) of identities, well-being, and perceived threat and examine how these measures develop while the corona virus continues to spread (t2 in two weeks and t3 in four weeks). The main question is: Do the levels of assimilation and differentiation increase during the corona crisis and how does that affect levels of group identities and well-being?

q1.value: Inclusion, Identity, and the Corona Pandemic

q3.value:
Brewer’s (1991) Optimal Distinctiveness Theory (ODT) suggests a two-dimensional model of inclusion (See Figure 1). She argues that for an individual to identify with a group, the individual does not only need to belong to other group members, but simultaneously satisfy authentic uniqueness needs. 
The outbreak of the COVID-19 virus in Europe in late February and early March has affected societies dramatically, such that schools and universities were closed, regions were isolated from the rest of the country, or travel bans were administered. Governments call citizens to responsibility, such that they ask to unify against this collective challenge and adhere to governmental regulations. Meanwhile, specific subgroups – such as individuals from particular areas, the elderly, chronically ill people, or families – have special needs that citizens are being asked to take care for. We thus expect this corona pandemic to increase both superordinate collective identity and subgroup identities as the virus develops. 
The virus seems to become a more serious issue in the US as of March 12th, 2020. We will thus immediately assess baseline measures (t1) of identities, well-being, and perceived threat and examine how these measures develop while the corona virus continues to spread (t2 in three weeks and t3 in six weeks). 
The main question is: Do the levels of perceived belonging and authentic uniqueness increase during the corona crisis and how does that affect levels of group identities and well-being? 

A summary of this pre-registration can be found in the PDF document "Pre-registration Inclusion, Identity, and the Corona Pandemic."

q4.value:
Increase of belonging. Research suggests that mortality salience increases cooperative and peace-promoting attitudes (Pyszczynski et al., 2012), as well as in-group norms (Van den Bos & Miedema, 2000) and group cohesion (Huddy, 2015). Moreover, politicians call for unity (e.g., the Austrian Chancellor: “We as the Republic of Austria are one team.”). 
In short, we expect that: 
H1. The level of belonging will increase during the three assessments. 
H2. The level of superordinate national identity will increase during the three assessments. 

Increase of uniqueness. Simultaneously, the acute situation may also increase the need for differentiation. Whereas identity threat was found to increase subordinate identification (Branscombe, Ellemers, Spears, & Doosje, 1999; Versteegen Master’s Thesis, in prep.), political decisions emphasize specific groups (e.g., with Trumps decision to refuse Europeans the entry into the U.S., Europeans are marked as the transmitters of the virus). Finally, specific demographic groups have own needs that tend to increase uniqueness (Reeve, 2014), such as the higher risk for chronically ill citizens, employees in industries that suffer from the economic decline, or families that have to organize themselves around school closures. In short, we expect that: 
H3: The level of uniqueness will increase during the three assessments. 
H4: The level of subordinate identities will increase during the three assessments. 

Belonging and uniqueness increase identity. In line with the Inclusion Identification Model (IIM; Adams, Meyers, Sekaja, and Versteegen, in prep.), we expect that inclusion (i.e., the feeling of belonging and authentic uniqueness) will increase identification with superordinate and subordinate identities. 
H5: Higher levels of belonging and uniqueness will be associated with higher superordinate identity. 
H6: Higher levels of belonging and uniqueness will be associated with higher subordinate identity.

Identification increases well-being. Whereas the corona pandemic will probably have a negative effect on life satisfaction and mental health, we expect that stronger superordinate and subordinate group identifications will be associated with better well-being (cf. Adams, et al., in prep.). We hypothesize that: 
H7: Stronger superordinate identity will be associated with higher well-being.
H8: Stronger subgroup identity will associated with higher well-being. 

Identity mediates the effect of belonging and uniqueness on well-being. The IIM (Adams et al., in prep.) suggests that higher levels of inclusion as conceptualized in ODT (Brewer, 1991) positively predict well-being because of higher superordinate and subordinate group identification. We thus hypothesize: 
H9: The effect of inclusion on well-being will be fully mediated by superordinate and subordinate identities.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a longitudinal design in which subjects take the questionnaire three times with a three-week break between each assessment.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Data will be collected via Amazon Turkprime. N = 200 participants will be invited to participate to participate in a first questionnaire. These participants will be contacted three and six weeks later to take follow-up questionnaires. We will contact them by emailing their anonymous MTurk worker ID.  

Participants will be included in the study if they are U.S. citizens and 18 years of age or older. No further exclusions are planned by now.

q13.value: A priori power analyses using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, & Lang, 2009) suggested a required sample size of N = 132 per study for two-tailed α =. 05, power = .8, and a small to medium effect size. Accounting for dropouts, we will collect N = 200 participants from Amazon Turkprime.

q15.value: TurkPrime will automatically stop the data collection in the first wave when the required sample size is being attained.

question.value:
Well-Being Dependent Variables
•	Life satisfaction (Satisfaction with Life Scale SWLS; Diener, Emmons, Larsen, & Griffin, 1985) 
•	Mental health (Short General Health Questionnaire, GHQ-5; Shamasunder, Sriram, Raj, & Shanmugham, 1986).

Identity Dependent Variables
•	Superordinate national identity (Huddy & Khatib, 2007).
•	In group ethnic identity (Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure, MEIM; Phinney, 1992).
•	In-group age identity (Age Identity scale; Garstka, Branscombe, & Hummert, 1997)-
•	In-group professional identity (adapted Marketing Professional Identity Scale; Bennet, 2010).
•	In-group family identity (adapted from the Marketing Professional Identity Scale; Bennet, 2010). 
•	In-group political identity (Partisan Identity Scale, PIS; Huddy, Mason, & Aarøe, 2015).
•	In-group chronic illness scale (adapted from Weinman, Petrie, Moss-Morris, & Horne, 1996, as well as Moss-Morris, Weinman, Petrie, Horne, Cameron, & Buick, 2002).

Virus-related variables
•	The virus may have effects on various parts of our daily lives. For example, travel freedom may be restricted, employees might have to work from home, the economy might experience a decline in orders, or people might have to go into social isolation. Please answer the following questions: 

•	How much do you try to keep yourself informed about the virus (e.g., via the media, experts, online research) (all 1 (Not at all) – 5 (Extremely))
•	How much does the virus affect your personal work life right now? 
•	How much does the virus affect your economic situation?
•	How much does the virus affect your personal social activities right now (e.g., you don’t want to go out anymore)? 
•	How much does the virus affect your family life (e.g., that your kids have to stay at home or that you do not want to visit your parents because of transmission risk)?
•	How much does the virus affect your consumption behavior (e.g., that you hoard groceries)
•	How much does the virus affect your long-term planning (e.g., that you don’t book summer travels)?
•	How much do you think it is necessary to stick together as U.S. citizens to cope with the pandemic? 
•	How much do you perceive the U.S. citizens stick together to cope with the pandemic?
•	How much do you think it is necessary to respond to needs of individual groups (e.g., of the elderly, of the chronically-ill, of affected industries)?
•	How much do you perceive the U.S. citizens respond to needs of those individual groups?
•	How much do you feel to belong to other U.S. citizens?
•	How much do you feel your individual needs to be seen, respected, and taken care of by other U.S. citizens? 
•	Are you still working? Yes/ No/ I usually don’t work
•	Have you been, are you currently, or are you planning to go in self-quarantine soon? Yes/No/I don’t know
•	Have you been diagnosed with the Covid-19 respiratory disease yet? Yes/No
•	How likely do you think you will be infected with the virus? (all 1 (Not at all) – 5 (Extremely))

Inclusion variables
•	10 items assessing belonging and authentic uniqueness, adapted form Salib (2014) to the U.S. American general sample context. 

Control variables
- basic background variables
- affect with the 10-item version the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988)

Superordinate national identity
In group ethnic identity (Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure, MEIM; Phinney, 1992).
In-group age identity (Age Identity scale; Garstka, Branscombe, & Hummert, 1997)-
In-group professional identity
In-group family identity 
In-group political identity
In-group chronic illness scale 
Life Satisfaction
Mental Health

H1: The mean belonging levels will be compared across the three measurement points by ordinary t-tests. 
H2: The mean superordinate identity levels will be compared across the three measurement points by ordinary t-tests.
H3: The mean uniqueness levels will be compared across the three measurement points by ordinary t-tests.
H4: The mean subordinate identity levels will be compared across the three measurement points by ordinary t-tests.
H5: Superordinate identity will be regressed in a hierarchical regression on belonging and uniqueness. Each hierarchical regression will have three models. Model 1 will only use the demographic variables as predictors. Model 2 will additionally include the PANAS affect control. Model 3 will additionally include the belonging and uniqueness variables. 
H6: Subordinate identities will be regressed on belonging and uniqueness in separate hierarchical regressions. Each hierarchical regression will have three models. Model 1 will only use the demographic variables as predictors. Model 2 will additionally include the PANAS affect control. Model 3 will additionally include the belonging and uniqueness variables.
H7: Both well-beings will be separately regressed on superordinate identity in a hierarchical regression. Each hierarchical regression will have three models. Model 1 will only use the demographic variables as predictors. Model 2 will additionally include the PANAS affect control. Model 3 will additionally include the superordinate identity.
H8: Both well-beings will be separately regressed on superordinate identity in a hierarchical regression. Each hierarchical regression will have three models. Model 1 will only use the demographic variables as predictors. Model 2 will additionally include the PANAS affect control. Model 3 will additionally include the subordinate identities.
H9: We will test the full mediation of belonging and uniqueness on well-being through superordinate and subordinate identities by means of Path Analyses, using the R-package lavaan. 

We will control for demographic variables (age, gender, relationship status, ethnicity, education level, occupation status, income, political orientation) and affect (Positive and Negative Affect Schedule, PANAS; Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988) in regressions.

q20.value:
Reverse-coded items in the scales will be recoded. As indicated above, a mean score
will be computed for the identity, well-being, and affect scales.
Categorical background variables as well as the condition will be
dummy coded.
No other data transformation is intended by now.

q21.value:
We will use p < .05 as criterion of significance, as well as the adequate effect size in
hierarchical regression and SEM.
In case of multiple comparisons, we will use the post-hoc Tukey-Kramer test as a
correction tool.

q22.value: We will exclude participations if we find indication that a subject has not paid attention to the questionnaire or has not taken it seriously.

q23.value:
The cause of potential missingness will be examined through missingness simulations
and, in case of missingness not at random (MNAR, Scheffer, 2002), we will consider conducting
maximum likelihood imputation.

q24.value:
Given the ongoing developments of the study context, we may consider explorative analyses in dependence of events that are not known yet. For example, President Trump has decided to refuse European citizens to enter the country on March 11th, 2020, which presumably would affect the identity of European citizens (because of identity threat). Likewise, if regulations target specific demographic groups (i.e., ethnicities), areas (i.e., a city being isolated), identities may be particularly affected there. This will then be considered in the analyses if possible. 
We will conduct exploratory analyses on the data in which we will evaluate mood as a first order mediator. The reasons for this is in the first experimental study we found that mood rather served as a first order mediator rather than a control variable (Adams, Meyers, Sekaja, & Versteegen, in prep.)
We may also test the data using Path analyses in Amos.

q25.value:
This project has received ethical clearance (Ethics code: EC-2019.Ex148t) 
Participants were informed about the study and debriefed according to APA guidelines (2010).

attributes.title: The effect of vaginal diazepam in treatment of pelvic pain related to non-relaxing pelvic floor dysfunction; a systematic review.

q1.value: The effect of vaginal diazepam in treatment of pelvic pain related to high tone pelvic floor dysfunction; a systematic review.

q3.value: The use of vaginal diazepam has been suggested as a treatment method for high tone pelvic floor dysfunction. Given that the literature is mixed as to the effectiveness of this medication for treatment, a systematic review of the literature may help to better clarify the best evidence-based practice for this treatment method.

q4.value: Vaginal diazepam is an effective method for treatment of pelvic pain related to high tone pelvic floor dysfunction.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A comprehensive review of gynecologic literature is to be performed by searching through two databases (PubMed, AJOG) for studies involving the use of vaginal diazepam in treatment of pelvic pain related to high tone pelvic floor dysfunction. Search terms include “vaginal diazepam” and “vaginal diazepam AND pelvic pain.” No limitation on study design or date. All study designs using vaginal diazepam for treatment of pelvic pain related to high tone pelvic floor dysfunction should be included for review. The subjects of the study must have been diagnosed with high tone pelvic floor dysfunction and subsequently treated with vaginal diazepam. Accepted methods of treatment include vaginal diazepam as monotherapy or vaginal diazepam as an adjuvant therapy. One of the primary or secondary outcomes assessed by the study must have included a subjective pain scale. Additional outcomes such as measurement of pelvic floor tone and assessment of dyspareunia were also accepted for assessment. Studies are not limited to randomized, placebo-controlled trials. Once all eligible studies are identified, the following information is to be obtained from each study and compared: 1) study type, 2) number of participants, 3) vaginal diazepam dosing and frequency, 4) study design, 5) results of the study, 6) conclusions of the study, and 7) GRADE scoring.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: A comprehensive review of gynecologic literature is to be performed by searching through two databases (PubMed, AJOG) for studies involving the use of vaginal diazepam in treatment of pelvic pain related to high tone pelvic floor dysfunction. Search terms include “vaginal diazepam” and “vaginal diazepam AND pelvic pain.” No limitation on study design or date. All study designs using vaginal diazepam for treatment of pelvic pain related to high tone pelvic floor dysfunction should be included for review. The subjects of the study must have been diagnosed with high tone pelvic floor dysfunction and subsequently treated with vaginal diazepam. Accepted methods of treatment include vaginal diazepam as monotherapy or vaginal diazepam as an adjuvant therapy. One of the primary or secondary outcomes assessed by the study must have included a subjective pain scale. Additional outcomes such as measurement of pelvic floor tone and assessment of dyspareunia were also accepted for assessment. Studies are not limited to randomized, placebo-controlled trials.

q13.value: Sample size dependent on number of qualifying studies.

question.value: Once all eligible studies are identified, the following information is to be obtained from each study and compared: 1) study type, 2) number of participants, 3) vaginal diazepam dosing and frequency, 4) study design, 5) results of the study, 6) conclusions of the study, and 7) GRADE scoring.
Dependent on it if able to perform a meta-analysis on the date in the studies.

registration_responses.q1: The effect of vaginal diazepam in treatment of pelvic pain related to high tone pelvic floor dysfunction; a systematic review.
registration_responses.q3: The use of vaginal diazepam has been suggested as a treatment method for high tone pelvic floor dysfunction. Given that the literature is mixed as to the effectiveness of this medication for treatment, a systematic review of the literature may help to better clarify the best evidence-based practice for this treatment method.
registration_responses.q4: Vaginal diazepam is an effective method for treatment of pelvic pain related to high tone pelvic floor dysfunction.
registration_responses.q5: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q13: Sample size dependent on number of qualifying studies.

All study designs using vaginal diazepam for treatment of pelvic pain related to high tone pelvic floor dysfunction should be included for review. The subjects of the study must have been diagnosed with high tone pelvic floor dysfunction and subsequently treated with vaginal diazepam. Accepted methods of treatment include vaginal diazepam as monotherapy or vaginal diazepam as an adjuvant therapy. One of the primary or secondary outcomes assessed by the study must have included a subjective pain scale. Additional outcomes such as measurement of pelvic floor tone and assessment of dyspareunia were also accepted for assessment. Studies are not limited to randomized, placebo-controlled trials. Once all eligible studies are identified, the following information is to be obtained from each study and compared: 1) study type, 2) number of participants, 3) vaginal diazepam dosing and frequency, 4) study design, 5) results of the study, 6) conclusions of the study, and 7) GRADE scoring.
registration_responses.q12.question: A comprehensive review of gynecologic literature is to be performed by searching through two databases (PubMed, AJOG) for studies involving the use of vaginal diazepam in treatment of pelvic pain related to high tone pelvic floor dysfunction. Search terms include “vaginal diazepam” and “vaginal diazepam AND pelvic pain.” No limitation on study design or date. All study designs using vaginal diazepam for treatment of pelvic pain related to high tone pelvic floor dysfunction should be included for review. The subjects of the study must have been diagnosed with high tone pelvic floor dysfunction and subsequently treated with vaginal diazepam. Accepted methods of treatment include vaginal diazepam as monotherapy or vaginal diazepam as an adjuvant therapy. One of the primary or secondary outcomes assessed by the study must have included a subjective pain scale. Additional outcomes such as measurement of pelvic floor tone and assessment of dyspareunia were also accepted for assessment. Studies are not limited to randomized, placebo-controlled trials.
registration_responses.q16.question: N/A
registration_responses.q17.question: Once all eligible studies are identified, the following information is to be obtained from each study and compared: 1) study type, 2) number of participants, 3) vaginal diazepam dosing and frequency, 4) study design, 5) results of the study, 6) conclusions of the study, and 7) GRADE scoring.
registration_responses.q19.question: Dependent on it if able to perform a meta-analysis on the date in the studies.

attributes.title: The Roles of Habit and Identity in Exercise Maintenance

summary.value: We have decided to terminate baseline data collection after March 13th, 2020. The institution where this data is being collected moved to online-only classes starting after the spring break period (March 16th-March 20th 2020) for at least two weeks (March 23rd- April 6th, 2020) due to the Coronavirus disease (i.e., COVID-19). Our original plan was to terminate data collection on April 17th, 2020. However, we believe that any possible data collection between the dates of April 6th and April 17th, 2020 may be abnormal given the Universities procedure. That is, participants may be less willing to frequent their normal exercise locations, especially those which are popular to the public. These public exercise facilities - such as gyms - will also likely be subject to closures. Additionally, students may not return to campus after the break and thus may have their normal exercise routine disrupted.

attributes.title: TEAM-LEVEL HUMAN RESOURCE ATTRIBUTIONS AND PERFORMANCE
attributes.description: Drawing on attribution theory, this study explores the relationship between team-level human resource attributions (HRAs) and team performance, and explains how transformational leadership moderates this relationship. The data were collected from leaders and subordinates across 77 work teams, for a total of 708 participants employed in seven manufacturing and service organizations in China. The study finds that the relationship between commitment-focused team-level HRAs and team performance is mediated by team engagement, and that transformational leadership significantly strengthens the positive relationship between these variables. However, these moderating and moderated mediation relationships are not evident between control-focused team-level HRAs and team performance. The study is among the first to explore team-level HRAs and contributes to the scholarly debates on the role of attributions in explaining the so-called “black box” between HRM and performance.

summary.value: Drawing on attribution theory, this study explores the relationship between team-level human resource attributions (HRAs) and team performance, and explains how transformational leadership moderates this relationship. However, these moderating and moderated mediation relationships are not evident between control-focused team-level HRAs and team performance. The study is among the first to explore team-level HRAs and contributes to the scholarly debates on the role of attributions in explaining the so-called “black box” between HRM and performance.

The study is among the first to explore team-level HRAs and contributes to the scholarly debates on the role of attributions in explaining the so-called “black box” between HRM and performance.

attributes.title: Discourse processing in  Aphasia: A systematic review

q1.value: Discourse processing in Aphasia and Right Hemisphere Damage: Systematic search and review

q3.value:
Aphasia is an acquired language disorder characterized by deficits in listening comprehension, verbal expression, reading, and writing that can result in significant community-based limitations even in its mildest form. Aphasia is typically caused after a stroke or a head injury, but it can also occur gradually from a slow-growing brain tumor or a disease that causes progressive, permanent damage (degenerative). Aphasia can be broadly divided into two types: fluent and non-fluent aphasia. The fluent aphasics typically have difficulty comprehending language whereas the non-fluent aphasics have difficulty expressing themselves. 
Right hemisphere brain damage, or RHD, is damage to the right side of the brain. The right hemisphere controls attention, memory, reasoning, and problem solving. RHD may lead to problems with these important thinking skills. A person with RHD may have trouble communicating with others because of this damage. In many cases, the person with RHD is not aware of his or her problems.
Discourse can be defined as any language beyond isolated sentences which aims to convey a message (Gee & Handford, 2012; Ulatowska & Olness, 2004). Discourse processing requires a complex interaction between linguistic processes to generate grammatical utterances (Kaan & Swaan, 2002), and cognitive systems, including executive function (Tun & Wingfield, 1994), episodic memory (Dijkstra, Bourgeois, Allen, & Burgio, 2004), semantic memory (Lambon Ralph, 2014), working memory (Marini, Boewe, Caltagirone, & Carlomagno, 2005) to comprehend and convey an overall message. 

Primary objective: Identifying different methods used to study discourse comprehension in persons with aphasia (PWA) and right-hemisphere damage (RHD). Specifically, the study will focus on identifying the stimulus types, the assessment methods that have been used to study discourse comprehension in PWA.
Secondary objective: Identifying how these studies contribute to assessment of discourse in the clinical setup.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is systematic search and review study.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: the data for this study will be published journal articles.

question.value: The articles will be collected using library databases.
We will study discourse comprehension in people with aphasia and right hemisphere damage.
A narrative description of discourse comprehension methods used for people with aphasia and RHD will be given.
Statistical models will not be used for this review.

attributes.title: Socializing Democrats: Examining Asian American Vote Choice with Evidence from a National Survey

q1.value: Socializing Democrats: Examining Asian American Vote Choice with Evidence from a National Survey

q5.value: I am grateful to the investigators of the National Asian American Study for collecting the data that made this study possible.

q8.value: Registration after researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Asian Americans are increasingly voting for Democrats in national elections. High levels of Democratic vote choice among Asian Americans are notable because many have high incomes, immigrated from countries with communist histories, or are Evangelical Christians. Why do Asian Americans support Democrats despite these conservative predispositions? I develop a novel theory of social transmission to explain Democratic vote choice among Asian Americans. The theory predicts that Asian Americans, who receive limited partisan socialization through the family, develop partisan preferences partly through the diffusion of political views within local contexts. This process leads to Democratic support because Asian Americans tend to settle in liberal metropolitan areas in the United States. I test this theory as an explanation for Asian American vote choice using data from the 2008 National Asian American Survey. The analyses also account for several alternative explanations including socioeconomic status, religion, national origin, group consciousness, and discrimination, and include several tests for the possibility of residential self-selection.

q16.value: I use two hypotheses to test the theory of social transmission. See the analysis plan for alterative hypotheses that I also test in this study. Local partisan context hypothesis: Asian Americans who live in Democratic counties are more likely to vote for Democrats than those who live in mixed partisan or Republican counties. Social integration hypothesis: Americans who are socially integrated into highly Democratic communities are more likely to vote for Democrats than their non-integrated counterparts.

q17.value: I use the 2008 National Asian American Survey (NAAS) to test these hypotheses as explanations for vote choice within the Asian American community (Ramakrishnan et al. 2008). The dataset includes respondents from a diverse range of national origin groups. The survey was conducted from August to October prior to the 2008 presidential election. The sample used in this analysis is restricted to 2,242 Asian Americans who indicated that they were U.S. citizens and were “very likely” to vote for a major party candidate in the 2008 presidential election. I use three logistic regression models to test the local partisan context hypothesis, both independently and in conjunction with alternative explanations. The dependent variable is a binary measure of intended vote choice in the presidential election. Vote choice equals one if the respondent intended to vote for the Democratic candidate and zero if they intended to vote for the Republican candidate. I identify whether the effects of local partisan context are maintained -- in direction, magnitude, and statistical significance -- after accounting for predictors of competing theories. The naive model only contains social transmission predictors. The main model adds religion, socioeconomic, and demographic predictors to the naive model. The full model adds national origin, discrimination and group consciousness predictors to the main model. These variables included in the analyses are described in detail in the analysis plan. I also conduct three analyses to test for the possibility of self-selection, which are described in the analysis plan.

attributes.title: Cardioprotective effect of electro-acupuncture for myocardial injury in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention: study protocol for a meta-analysis and systematic review
